answer:
Frame‐by‐Frame Analysis:

• Frame 1: The bus is traveling downhill in the same central travel lane as the ego vehicle. The street appears straight, with parking on both sides. No visible turn signals or lane markings suggest a required turn. No signage indicates a forced left or right.  
• Frame 2: The bus remains centered in the lane, continuing straight down the slope. Still no sign of lane‐changing or turning—its position is consistent with going forward.  
• Frame 3: The bus proceeds downhill, no lateral movement toward a side street. There do not appear to be arrows on the pavement directing traffic to turn.  
• Frame 4: The bus is nearing the intersection but remains aligned with the lane’s center. No visible turn signal or lane shift toward a left‐ or right‐turn position.  
• Frame 5: The bus keeps straight with no sign of initiation of a turn. The intersection has a stop sign, but nothing suggests the bus is about to turn left or right.

Contextual Reasoning:
Across all five frames, the bus holds its straight path in the travel lane. Buses typically follow main routes along the roadway. No turn signals or road markings hint at a turn, and no unusual maneuver such as reversing is indicated. The intersection ahead has a stop sign, but nothing suggests a pending turn or reverse action.

Match to Answer Choices:
• Turn Left (A): No left‐turn signal or lane shift observed. Unlikely.  
• Go Straight (B): The bus maintains a forward path, with no sign of turning. This is most consistent with the frames.  
• Turn Right (C): No sign of a right‐turn signal or positioning. Unlikely.  
• Reverse (D): No indication the bus is backing up.  

Provide the Best Answer:
The bus is most likely continuing straight ahead.

<answer>B. Go straight.</answer>
